case_name: Co-operative Society v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: This is an appeal with special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Shah, J. This is an appeal with special leave.

facts.text: The appellant is a Society registered under the Co-operative Societies Act, 1912.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a Society registered under the Co-operative Societies Act, 1912.

facts.text: Data relates to the year ending June 30, 1955, relevant to assessment year 1956-57.

anchor.surface_text: The following table sets out the data relating to the earnings, investments, working capital, outgoings and expenditure of the Society for the year ending June 30, 1955, relevant to the assessment year 1956-57

facts.text: Society claimed under s. 14(3) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 as added by s.10 Finance Act 1955 eff April 1, 1955 that income from business was exempt from tax.

anchor.surface_text: In a proceeding for assessment of the total income of the Society to tax for the year 1956-57 it was claimed that under s. 14 3  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922  as added by s. 10 of the Finance Act 1955, with effect from April 1, 1955  the income of the Society from business was exempt from payment of tax

facts.text: Out of gross income from securities Rs. 4,30,053, Rs. 4,16,475 attributable to assets utilized in business, balance Rs. 13,578 chargeable to tax per instructions under s.60.

anchor.surface_text: , and that in accordance with the instructions issued under s. 60 of the Act, out of the gross income from securities amounting to Rs. 4,30,053/- Rs. 4,16,475/- being income attributable to the assets utilized in the business, only the balance of Rs. 13,578/- was chargeable to tax.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held Society could not claim benefit of Departmental Instructions as they ceased to operate, applied Explanation to s.8 per Finance Act 1956 eff April 1, 1956, computed taxable income Rs. 59,498.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the Income-tax Officer the Society companyld number claim the benefit of the Departmental Instructions, since in the relevant year of assessment those instructions had ceased to operate, and the Societys claim was governed by the Explanation to s. 8 of the Income-tax Act as incorporated by the Finance Act of 1956, with effect from April 1, 1956. He accordingly companyputed the taxable income under the head - interest on securities in the sum of Rs. 59,498/-

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner modified ITO order, reduced taxable income to Rs. 13,578 applying Departmental Instructions, held Explanation to s.8 applies only to Banking Companies not Co-operative Societies.

anchor.surface_text: . The Appellate Assistant Commissioner modified the order of the Income-tax Officer and reduced the taxable income under the head interest on securities to Rs. 13,578/- applying the Departmental Instructions. He held that the Explanation to s. 8 of the Act applied to Banking Companies and number to Co-operative Societies.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal reversed AAC, restored ITO order, held Explanation to s.8 not applicable as not banking company but principle applicable, relief Rs.59,498.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal by the Commissioner of Income-tax the Appellate Tribunal reversed the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, and restored the order of the Income-tax Officer. In the view of the Tribunal, the Explanation to s. 8 of the Act cannot be invoked as the Society was number a Banking Company, but the principle of the Explanation may well be called in aid and that the relief granted by the Income-tax Officer was the only relief to which the Society was entitled.

facts.text: Tribunal submitted question to High Court of Madras: Whether Tribunal justified in holding taxable income from interest on securities Rs.59,498?

anchor.surface_text: The following question of law was submitted by the Tribunal to the High Court of Madras Whether the Tribunal is justified in law in holding that the taxable income of the assessee from interest on securities is Rs. 59,498/- ?

facts.text: High Court reframed question to whether taxable income Rs.13,578 as per assessee and Dept instructions, answered in favour of Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court reframed the question to read Whether the taxable income of the assessee from interest on securities is Rs. 13,578/- as companytended by the assessee and as worked out on the basis of the Departmental instructions companytained at pages 248 and 249 in Part III of the year 1946 ?, and answered it in favour of the Commissioner.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, held Rs.13,578 taxable based on proportion of working capital used in business to total.

anchor.surface_text: The proportion of income from securities which is exempt from taxation under s. 14  3  of the Act will be that proportion which the capital of the Society used for the purpose of the business bears to the total working capital. It is admitted that Rs. 13,578/- is the gross income from securities which is, according to that rule, liable to tax.

facts.text: Departmental instructions issued under s.60, notification August 25, 1925, modified June 25, 1927, October 20, 1934, August 18, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Act, 1922, as originally enacted, did number give to a Co-operative Society exemption from payment of tax in respect of income from its business activities. But by Departmental Instructions issued under s. 60 of the Act, certain exemptions were given by a numberification issued on August 25, 1925 and modified by numberifications dated June 25, 1927, October 20, 1934 and August 18, 1945.

facts.text: Society is not a Banking Company.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the Tribunal, the Explanation to s. 8 of the Act cannot be invoked as the Society was number a Banking Company,

facts.text: Departmental notification relied upon by Society was withdrawn before relevant assessment year.

facts.text: Rs. 13,578 is admitted as the gross income from securities liable to tax per the rule of apportionment based on working capital.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that Rs. 13,578/- is the gross income from securities which is, according to that rule, liable to tax.

issues.text: Whether the Explanation to s. 8 applies to the co-operative society

anchor.surface_text: He held that the Explanation to s. 8 of the Act applied to Banking Companies and not to Co-operative Societies. In appeal by the Commissioner of Income-tax the Appellate Tribunal reversed the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, and restored the order of the Income-tax Officer. In the view of the Tribunal, the Explanation to s. 8 of the Act cannot be invoked as the Society was not a Banking Company

issues.text: What is the correct rule of apportionment of income from Government securities between business activity (exempt) and non-business activity (taxable)

anchor.surface_text: There is, therefore, no statutory rule, and no there are departmental instructions, governing the apportionment of income from Government securities between business and non-business sources of income. It was never urged, and it cannot be urged, that in the absence of a specific rule for apportionment, the entire income from Government securities should be brought to tax. Any attempt to bring the entire income from Government securities would infringe s. 14 3  of the Act. A rule of apportionment consistent with commercial accounting must be evolved for determining

arguments.claim: Under s.14(3) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 (as added by Finance Act 1955), income from business is exempt from tax, and per instructions under s.60, only Rs. 13,578 out of gross income from securities is chargeable to tax

anchor.surface_text: In a proceeding for assessment of the total income of the Society to tax for the year 1956-57 it was claimed that under s. 14 3  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922  as added by s. 10 of the Finance Act 1955, with effect from April 1, 1955  the income of the Society from business was exempt from payment of tax, and that in accordance with the instructions issued under s. 60 of the Act, out of the gross income from securities amounting to Rs. 4,30,053/- Rs. 4,16,475/- being income attributable to the assets utilized in the business, only the balance of Rs. 13,578/- was chargeable to tax.

arguments.court_reasoning: Proportion of income exempt is that which business capital bears to total working capital; Rs. 13,578 admitted as liable to tax per this rule

arguments.claim: Society cannot claim benefit of Departmental Instructions as they ceased to operate in relevant year; claim governed by Explanation to s.8 (Finance Act 1956), taxable income from securities Rs. 59,498

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the Income-tax Officer the Society could not claim the benefit of the Departmental Instructions, since in the relevant year of assessment those instructions had ceased to operate, and the Society's claim was governed by the Explanation to s. 8 of the Income-tax Act as incorporated by the Finance Act of 1956, with effect from April 1, 1956. He accordingly computed the taxable income under the head - interest on securities in the sum of Rs. 59,498/-

In the view of the Tribunal, the Explanation to s. 8 of the Act cannot be invoked as the Society was not a Banking Company, but the principle of the Explanation may well be called in aid and that the relief granted by the Income-tax Officer was the only relief to which the Society was entitled.

anchor.surface_text: There is also no dispute that the departmental notification relied upon by the company was withdrawn before the relevant assessment year.

arguments.claim: Benefit of departmental notification not available as deemed withdrawn; Explanation to s.8 does not in terms apply to Society

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the benefit of the departmental notification was not available to the Society in the year of assessment, because it must be deemed to be withdrawn and the Explanation to s. 8 did not in term apply to the Society.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: om Government securities between business and number-business sources of income. It was never urged, and it cannot be urged, that in the absence of a

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed, no dispute on withdrawal; Explanation expressly for banking companies

arguments.claim: Explanation to s.8 has no application to co-operative society not carrying on banking business

anchor.surface_text: It was common ground between the parties in this Court and the High Court that Explanation to s. 8 has no application to a co-operative society which does not carry on the business of a banking company.

arguments.claim: No statutory rule or departmental instructions govern apportionment of income from securities between business and non-business; entire income cannot be taxed as infringes s.14(3)

anchor.surface_text: There is, therefore, no statutory rule, and no there are departmental instructions, governing the apportionment of income from Government securities between business and non-business sources of income. It was never urged, and it cannot be urged, that in the absence of a specific rule for apportionment, the entire income from Government securities should be brought to tax. Any attempt to bring the entire income from Government securities would infringe s. 14 3  of the Act.

arguments.claim: Rule of apportionment consistent with commercial accounting: proportion of income from securities exempt/taxable is that which business capital bears to total working capital; Rs. 13,578 taxable
Explanation to s.8 provides artificial rules for allocating expenses/outgoings in banking companies, not suitable for apportioning composite income partly taxable/partly exempt

anchor.surface_text: The rule contained in clause a of the Explanation to s. 8 has specially been evolved for determining the appropriate outgoings for the purpose of realizing interest from securities held by a Banking Company ... The problem arising under s. 14 3  is of apportionment of income under heads taxable and non-taxable it is not a problem relating to allocation of outgoings to determine taxable income. In our judgment, a rule of apportionment which dismembers income in proportion to the business and non-business components of the single source from which it arises would be more consistent with principles of commercial accounting.

holdings.text: Explanation to s. 8 has no application to a co-operative society which does not carry on the business of a banking company.

anchor.surface_text: It was common ground between the parties in this Court and the High Court that Explanation to s. 8 has no application to a co-operative society which does not carry on the business of a banking company.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Common ground between parties; Explanation expressly limited to banking companies by its terms.

holdings.text: The departmental notification relied upon by the Society was withdrawn before the relevant assessment year.

anchor.surface_text: There is also no dispute that the departmental notification relied upon by the company was withdrawn before the relevant assessment year.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No dispute on the fact of withdrawal; instructions ceased to operate for the assessment year.

holdings.text: There is no statutory rule or departmental instructions governing the apportionment of income from Government securities between business and non-business sources; entire income cannot be brought to tax as it infringes s.14(3).

anchor.surface_text: There is, therefore, no statutory rule, and no there are departmental instructions, governing the apportionment of income from Government securities between business and non-business sources of income. It was never urged, and it cannot be urged, that in the absence of a specific rule for apportionment, the entire income from Government securities should be brought to tax. Any attempt to bring the entire income from Government securities would infringe s. 14 3  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Confirmed withdrawal and absence of rules; s.14(3) mandates exemption for business portion requiring apportionment.

holdings.text: The rule contained in the Explanation to s.8 is an artificial rule for allocating outgoings and expenses in banking companies, not for apportioning composite income between taxable and exempt portions.

anchor.surface_text: The rule contained in clause a of the Explanation to s. 8 has specially been evolved for determining the appropriate outgoings for the purpose of realizing interest from securities held by a Banking Company ... The problem arising under s. 14 3  is of apportionment of income under heads taxable and non-taxable it is not a problem relating to allocation of outgoings to determine taxable income. In our judgment, a rule of apportionment which dismembers income in proportion to the business and non-business components of the single source from which it arises would be more consistent with principles of commercial accounting.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explanation deals with expense allocation proportional to receipts, not income dismemberment between business/non-business; Tribunal erred in applying its principle.

holdings.text: A rule of apportionment consistent with commercial accounting must be evolved: the proportion of income from securities exempt under s.14(3) is that which the capital used for business bears to total working capital.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory/dept rule; Explanation unsuitable; commercial principles require income apportionment by capital proportions for business/non-business use.

holdings.text: Rs. 13,578 is the gross income from securities liable to tax according to the rule of apportionment.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that Rs. 13,578/- is the gross income from securities which is, according to that rule, liable to tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admitted figure resulting from application of capital proportion rule to society's facts.

holdings.text: The Tribunal is not justified in holding taxable income from interest on securities as Rs.59,498; the taxable income is Rs.13,578 as per the High Court reframed question.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the Tribunal is justified in law in holding that the taxable income of the assessee from interest on securities is Rs. 59,498/- ? ... Whether the taxable income of the assessee from interest on securities is Rs. 13,578/- as contended by the assessee and as worked out on the basis of the Departmental instructions contained at pages 248 and 249 in Part III of the year 1946 ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects Tribunal's reliance on Explanation principle; applies commercial capital proportion yielding Rs.13,578.

anchor.surface_text: There is, therefore, no statutory rule, and no there are departmental instructions, governing the apportionment of income from Government securities between business and non-business sources of income. It was never urged, and it cannot be urged, that in the absence of a specific rule for apportionment, the entire income from Government securities should be brought to tax. Any attempt to bring the entire income from Government securities would infringe s. 14 3  of the Act.

The appeal is allowed. Answer to the question as reframed by the High Court is that Rs. 13,578/- are taxable as income of the Society received from Government securities under s. 8 of the Income-tax Act.

edges.explanation: h4 holds that the rule in the Explanation to s.8 (c7) is an artificial rule for banking companies allocating outgoings and expenses, not for apportioning composite income between taxable and exempt sources

anchor.surface_text: ose of realizing interest, a part there for which is equal to the proportion which the gross receipts from interest on securities chargeable to tax, b

edges.explanation: h4 clarifies that s.8 Explanation does not apply for apportionment, supporting h3's no statutory rule holding

anchor.surface_text: The rule contained in clause a of the Explanation to s. 8 has specially been evolved for determining the appropriate outgoings for the purpose of realizing interest from securities held by a Banking Company ... The problem arising under s. 14 3  is of apportionment of income under heads taxable and non-taxable it is not a problem relating to allocation of outgoings to determine taxable income. In our judgment, a rule of apportionment which dismembers income in proportion to the business and non-business components of the single source from which it arises would be more consistent with principles of commercial accounting.
